medical_history.history_of_present_illness: Two days prior to presentation, the patient experienced sudden onset of abdominal pain in the left upper quadrant, radiating to the back in a bandlike pattern across the subcostal margin. The abdominal pain was associated with nausea and early satiety, worsening with movement. Over two days, the intensity of abdominal discomfort increased from 3 to 6 on a 10-point scale. Additionally, he reported substernal chest pressure which developed the day before presentation, consistent with his usual angina but unresponsive to sublingual nitroglycerin. The pain diminished with administration of three sublingual nitroglycerin tablets in the emergency department but resolved only after the administration of intravenous morphine, ketorolac, and chewable aspirin.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Coronary artery disease, dyslipidemia, hypertension, myocardial infarction at age 32, coronary-artery bypass grafting, chronic diarrhea after bypass surgery, appendectomy.
medical_history.family_history: Colon cancer, prostate cancer, coronary artery disease in the father.
medical_history.social_history: The patient works as a nurse, drinks two beers every other day, has had remote work-related blood exposure to HIV and hepatitis B and C (tests were negative), does not smoke or use illicit drugs.
